isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - ROCKWELL 9, 10, AND 13 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS - ASSEMBLE - NINE- AND TEN-SPEED AUXILIARY

note.para: The bearing cup and bearing cone must be replaced as an assembly. Do not replace the cup or the cone separately. Replace the cup and cone in a matched set from the same manufacturer.

step1.para: Lubricate all the parts of the auxiliary cover with the oil used in the transmission. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

On Design Level 1 Nine-Speed Transmissions, if removed, install the snap ring in the groove inside the auxiliary low gear. Make sure the round side of the snap ring is installed toward the gear ( Figure 204).
Put timing marks on the auxiliary low gear. Mark one tooth with paint. Mark a second tooth opposite (180 degrees) the first tooth ( Figure 204).

figure.caption: Figure 204. Put Timing Marks on Auxiliary Low Gear

step1.para: Use paint to put timing marks next to each other on two teeth of each countershaft low gear. Make sure the mark is aligned with the "O" stamping on the countershaft ( Figure 205).

figure.caption: Figure 205. Put Timing Marks Next to Each Other

step1.para: Assemble the output shaft and low gear assembly according to the following procedure ( Figure 206):

step2.para: Put the output shaft on the work bench. Make sure the threaded end of the shaft is up.
On Design Level 1, Model 115 and 125 Transmissions, install the output shaft spacer with the shoulder. Make sure the spacer is installed with the large section toward the bottom of the shaft.

On Design Level 1, Model 135 and 145 Transmissions, install the output shaft spacer with the shoulder. Make sure the spacer is installed with the large section toward the bottom of the shaft. Install the small spacer on top of the spacer with the shoulder.
On Design Level 2, Model 115 and 125 Transmissions, install the flat output shaft spacer on the shaft.
On Design Level 2, Model 155 and 165 Transmissions, install the large output shaft spacer on the shaft. Install the small output shaft spacer on top of the large spacer.
On Design Level 1 Nine-Speed Transmissions, install the toothed spacer in the low gear.
On Design Level 1 Nine-Speed Transmissions, install the snap ring in the low gear.
Install the auxiliary low gear on the output shaft ( Figure 206).
On Design Level 1 Nine-Speed Transmissions, install the thrust washer on top of the low gear (Figure 206).

figure.caption: Figure 206. Assemble Output Shaft and Low Gear Assembly

warning.para: The bearing cone may be heated to ease installation. Insulated gloves or similar protection should be worn to prevent burns.

step1.para: Put the output shaft and low gear assembly on a press. Support the shaft on the bottom of the shaft. Make sure the threads on the shaft are toward the top of the press.
Install a bearing cone on the shaft. Make sure the large diameter of the gear is toward the cone ( Figure 207).
Put a sleeve on the cone. Press the cone on the shaft until the cone touches the thrust washer or the low gear. Make sure the gear and bearing cone rotate on the shaft.
Install the spacer on the shaft ( Figure 208).
Put the cover in a press so that the outside is toward the top of the press. Support the cover under the output shaft bore ( Figure 209).
Put the inner bearing cup in the cover. Make sure the letters on the cup are toward you. Install a sleeve or a bearing installation tool on the race of the bearing (Figure 209).
Press the inner cup into the cover (Figure 209).

figure.caption: Figure 209. Press Inner Cup into Cover

step1.para: Put the outer cup on top of the inner cup. Make sure the slots of the outer cup are against the inner cup ( Figure 210).

figure.caption: Figure 210. Put Outer Cup on Top of Inner Cup

step1.para: Put a sleeve on installation tool on the top of the outer cup. Press both cups into the bore. The cups are correctly installed when the outer cup touches the shoulder in the bore of the cover ( Figure 211).

figure.caption: Figure 211. Press Both Cups into Bore

warning.para: A bearing heater can be used to install the bearing cone. Follow the instructions of the manufacturer of the bearing heater. Wear gloves or other protective clothing to prevent personal injury while handling the heated bearing.

step1.para: Put the countershaft in a press so that the front of the countershaft is toward the top of the press. Support the countershaft on the gear.
Put the front cone on the countershaft so that the bottom of the cone is toward the gear (Figure 212).
Put a sleeve on the inner race of the cone. Press the cone on the countershaft. The cone is correctly installed when the bottom of the cone touches the gear (Figure 212).
Turn the shaft over so that the opposite end is toward the top of the press. Repeat steps 15 through 17 to install the rear cone.
Put the output shaft and low gear assembly in a press. Make sure the threads on the shaft are toward the top of the press (Figure 212).

figure.caption: Figure 212. Press Cone on Countershaft and Put Output Shaft and Low Gear Assembly in a Press

step1.para: Put each auxiliary countershaft next to the output shaft. Make sure the timing marks on each countershaft and low gear are aligned (Figure 213).

figure.caption: Figure 213. Make Sure Timing Marks are Aligned

step1.para: Put the auxiliary cover on the output shaft and low gear assembly and auxiliary countershafts ( Figure 214).
Install the outer bearing cone on the output shaft. Make sure the letters on the cone are toward the top of the press.
Install a sleeve on the outer bearing cone. Press the cone on the shaft and into the cup in the bore of the cover (Figure 215).
Support the output shaft so that the cover is in the upright position.
Make sure the timing marks on the low gear and each auxiliary countershaft are in alignment.
Install the synchronizer assembly on the output shaft inside the auxiliary cover. Make sure the high synchronizer is toward you (Figure 216).
Install the correct cup on the rear bearing of the upper auxiliary countershaft ( Figure 217).
Install the correct cup on the rear bearing of the lower auxiliary countershaft (Figure 217).

figure.caption: Figure 217. Install Cups on Rear Bearings

step1.para: Design Level 1 Nine-Speed Transmission: Install the snap ring that retains the cups in the case. Use the snap ring that was removed during disassembly.
Design Level 2 Nine-Speed and Ten-Speed Transmissions: Install the selective washers in front of the cups. Make sure the tabs on the washers are in the slots in the case ( Figure 218).
Install Holding Cover Tools on each countershaft. Use bolts to fasten the cover tools to the countershafts and cover (Figure 218).
If removed, use a suitable tool to install a new bushing for the speedometer gear inside the output bearing retainer.

Use a sealant dispenser and Loctite RTV Sealant or equivalent to make a 2 mm (1/8 inch) sealant pattern for the output bearing retainer. Make sure the sealant material does not cover the oil passage. Refer to Figure 219for the sealant pattern. Refer to INSTALL THE SEALANT section.

Install the output bearing retainer on the auxiliary cover. Make sure the oil passage in the retainer is aligned over the oil hole in the cover ( Figure 220). Tighten the bolts to 47 to 61 Nm (35 to 45 ft-lbs.).
Install the oil seal in the output bearing retainer (Figure 221).

caution.para: Hold the seal only on the outer diameter. Do not touch the inner diameter of the seal. Touching contaminates the inner diameter of the seal and causes a leak between shaft and seal.

step1.para: Lubricate the outer diameter of the seal. Make sure the letters on the seal are installed away from the retainer.

caution.para: Use the correct tool to install the oil seal. If the correct tool is not used, the seal will leak.

step1.para: Use seal driver tool ZTSE-4424 to drive the seal into the cover. The seal is correctly installed when the outer flange of the seal touches the retainer.

Put the HI-LO shift fork in position so that the fork engages the synchronizer collar. Make sure the bore of the fork is aligned with the bore of the range cylinder. Make sure the hole in the fork is installed away from the cover ( Figure 222).
Install the HI-LO shift shaft from inside the front of the auxiliary cover. Make sure the threads on the end of the shaft are installed first (Figure 222).

note.para: If a pin and clip were used to fasten the HI-LO fork to the shaft, replace the pin and clip with a nut and shoulder bolt.

step1.para: Align the hole of the shaft with the hole of the shift fork. Install the bolt and the lock nut. Tighten the nut to 11 to 16 Nm (8 to 12 ft-lbs.) ( Figure 223).

figure.caption: Figure 223. Install Bolt and Lock Nut

caution.para: Do not use too much silicone lubricant on the O-rings and bore of the range cylinder housing. If too much lubricant is used, the range may shift slowly.

step1.para: Lubricate the O-rings and bore of the range cylinder housing with a silicone lubricant such as Dow Corning #111 Silicone Grease or equivalent. Install the O-ring in the groove in the bore of the range cylinder housing (Figure 224).

Use a sealant dispenser and Loctite RTV Sealant or equivalent to make a 3 mm (1/8 inch) sealant pattern for the range cylinder housing. Refer to Figure 225 for the sealant pattern. Refer to INSTALLING THE SEALANT section. Install the range cylinder housing on the auxiliary cover.

Lubricate the O-rings for the piston with a silicone lubricant such as Dow Corning #111 Silicone Grease or equivalent. Install the O-rings on the outer diameter and inner diameter of the piston (Figure 226).
Install the piston on the shaft in the range cylinder. Install the nut that fastens the piston on the shaft. Tighten the nut to 47 to 68 Nm (35 to 50 ft-lbs.) ( Figure 227).
Install the gasket between the range cylinder cover and the range cylinder housing. Install the cover.
Install the bolts and washers that fasten the range cylinder cover to the auxiliary cover. Tighten the bolts to 47 to 61 Nm (35 to 45 ft-lbs.).
Put the auxiliary cover in the LO range.
Clean the outer diameter of the cups for the front bearing cones of the auxiliary countershafts. Put the cups in the correct bores in the transmission case (Figure 228).

figure.caption: Figure 228. Put Cups in Correct Bores
